awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Transformative Modeling Studies of Magnetosphere-Ionosphere/Thermosphere System
awd_abstract_narration:
The space environment surrounding the Earth is extremely dynamic, responding rapidly to the changing plasma and electromagnetic fields arriving from the Sun. Storms in space can trigger explosively (like earthquakes and volcanoes), driving strong electric currents through the upper atmosphere, which induce currents in the solid earth that can disrupt power grids; redistributing the charged particles within the embedded layers of the ionosphere, which can interfere with GPS navigation systems; and heating the upper atmosphere, which increases drag degrading the orbits of satellites. Global models of the high-altitude geospace environment are electromagnetic in nature and can follow these rapid changes in the magnetic fields and currents surrounding Earth, not so models of the magnetically coupled lower altitude ionosphere/upper atmosphere, which are electrostatic in nature. This proposal is focused on the development of a first-of-its-kind global electromagnetic model of the ionosphere/upper atmosphere system that, if successful will ultimately be incorporated into next-generation space weather models. This project is appropriate for the EAGER program.  It is high risk but the reward, if it succeeds, is a new generation of global magnetosphere-ionosphere models that could potentially change views on some of the most fundamental aspects of the coupling between space and the upper atmosphere during the rapid onset of disturbances and possibly trigger new discoveries by supplying predictions of other effects to search for in the observations. The results will ultimately improve capabilities for space weather prediction and are potentially of interest to the study of planetary atmospheres, accretion disks, nebula, and the interstellar medium.  The training of a graduate student at the University of Massachusetts-Lowell on this grant is an excellent means of transferring knowledge about this complex numerical methodology to the next generation of space scientists and is a near-term broader impact.

Present models of the ionosphere-thermosphere assume that the magnetic field close to Earth is constant.  But fast time-scale processes like explosive auroral activity are not correctly represented unless the changes in the magnetic field produced by electric currents closing through the ionosphere are solved for self-consistently. A major impediment to developing such a model using present explicit numerical algorithms has been the intractably short time steps (as short as 1 millionth of a second at 100 kilometers altitude) required to maintain stability of the solution, which dictate unrealistically long computer run times in order to follow the evolution of the system. The PI is implementing new numerical technology not widely known in the geospace community based on implicit algorithms that enable the use of much longer time steps, and also optimizing the model to run on high-performance computers.  The new electromagnetic model will then be used in a number of numerical experiments to explore controversial features of rapidly developing disturbances in the coupled geospace - upper atmosphere system.

por.por_cntn:
The geospace surrounding the Earth is filled with tenuous charged particles (electrons and roughly equal amount of ions, called plasma), an environment that is extremely dynamic, responding rapidly to the disturbances in the solar wind (also a plasma) and electromagnetic fields arriving from the Sun. Such disturbance often cause geomagnetic storms that may have serious impacts on the modern technology infrastructures, via such processes as geomagnetically induced currents in the power grids, spacecraft charging and orbit altering, communication disruption, and navigation errors. Understanding physical processes underlying dynamic responses of the geospace to the disturbances in the solar wind is therefore critical to develop capability of space weather forecasting. Because geospace environment is electromagnetic in nature, theory and simulation models of the geospace including magnetosphere (high-altitude geospace) and ionosphere/upper atmosphere (lower-altitude geospace) must include solutions of electromagnetic fields instead of just electrostatic electric fields. Present models of the ionosphere/upper atmosphere assume that the electric and magnetic field do not change with time. This is obviously intrinsically inconsistent with the observations of a large time varying current during disturbance times, which produces large magnetic field perturbations, which in turn induce time-varying electric field. Because of this caveat, fast time-scale processes like explosive auroral activities are not correctly described by the existing models.

In this project we have successfully developed a first-of-its-kind global electromagnetic model of the inner magnetosphere-ionosphere/upper atmosphere system, which will ultimately be incorporated into next-generation space weather models. This model provides a transformative modeling framework by retaining solutions of Maxwell’s equations in the ionosphere (not only magnetosphere) and using cutting-edge high performance computing techniques, including implicit numerical algorithm that greatly increase the time step in advancing the solutions. Incorporation of the solutions of the Maxwell’s equations in the ionosphere makes the model unique and capable of rendering faithful explanation of the dynamic changes of the M-IT system. The cutting-edge high performance computing techniques adapted in the model greatly increased model execution speed. Without these new numerical techniques, a single simulation of this kind of model would take more than one year to run even just modeling a real time of several hours. This slow speed of the simulations, which is dictated by the intractably short time step (as short as 1 millionth of a second at 100 kilometers altitude) to maintain stability of solutions if explicit numerical algorithm is used, has been the single factor that prevents self-consistent global simulation models of this kind from being possible. The existing models have to sacrifice the self-consistency for the speed, leading to the incapability of some key dynamic space weather phenomena, such as magnetic substorms, or tornados in a weather analogy if solar storms and magnetic storms are analogous to hurricanes. The new model will provide the possibility to simulate these processes.

The model developed has been applied to study the responses of the ionosphere to the imposed disturbances from the magnetosphere in both dawn-dusk meridian and noon-midnight meridian. The simulation demonstrates the dynamic processes of self-consistent formation of the electric currents, magnetic field perturbations, and electric field in the ionosphere. In the fast time varying stage of the ionosphere, the magnetosphere and ionosphere is coupled via the Alfven waves (a low frequency electromagnetic wave in the plasma) instead of through electric currents flowing along the Earth’s magnetic field lines or electric field mapping as described in the convectional magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling models. The global response of the ionosphere is caused by the coupling of the high-to-low latitude ionosphere through primarily the fast-mode magnetosonic wave (another kind of low frequency electromagnetic wave unique in the plasma) propagating form the high latitude towards the equator. These discoveries reveal a completely new view of the ionosphere dynamics during the disturbed times. These new insights will eventually lead to new understanding of magnetic substorms, one of the least understood phenomena in space physics.
